articles.author: Herbert Lash
articles.title: GLOBAL MARKETS-Oil, safe havens surge after U.S. strikes kill Iran commander
articles.description: Oil prices surged as much as $3 a barrel as gold, the yen and safe-haven bonds all rallied on Friday after the U.S. killing of Iran's top military commander in an air strike in Iraq ratcheted up tensions between Washington and Tehran.
articles.content:
(Adds close of U.S. markets) 
* Killing of Iranian commander douses equity market rally 
* Oil, gold prices surge after strike in Baghdad 
* Scramble for safety boosts yen, Swiss franc, Bunds 
* European, U.S. shares fall less than 1% 
By Herbert Lash an… [+5062 chars]

articles.author: Reuters Editorial
articles.title: Bears hand S Jackson $58.4 million contract
articles.description: Chicago Bears safety Eddie Jackson agreed to a four-year contract worth $58.4 million, making him the NFL's highest-paid player in average annual value at the position.
articles.content:
Chicago Bears safety Eddie Jackson agreed to a four-year contract worth $58.4 million, making him the NFL’s highest-paid player in average annual value at the position. 
The deal with the Pro Bowl defensive back averages $14.6 million a year. 
Jackson’s age… [+614 chars]

articles.author: Vishwadha Chander
articles.title: People with mental illness less likely to get cancer screening
articles.description: (Reuters Health) - People with mental illness get screened for cancer at much lower rates than the general population, which may contribute to higher rates of cancer deaths among the mentally ill, researchers say.
articles.content:
(Reuters Health) - People with mental illness get screened for cancer at much lower rates than the general population, which may contribute to higher rates of cancer deaths among the mentally ill, researchers say.

articles.author: Reuters Editorial
articles.title: Stalemate in Senate over Trump impeachment
articles.description: The U.S. Senate remained at a stalemate on Friday over how to proceed with the impeachment trial of President Donald Trump, as the chamber's leaders continued a dispute over whether top White House aides will be called as witnesses. Jillian Kitchener has more.

articles.author: Reuters Editorial
articles.title: Spain's electoral board orders Catalan leader stripped of lawmaker role
articles.description: Spain's electoral board on Friday ordered the pro-independence president of Catalonia's government be stripped of his regional lawmaker role, in a move that may complicate efforts to end a prolonged national political deadlock.
articles.content:
MADRID (Reuters) - Spain’s electoral board on Friday ordered the pro-independence president of Catalonia’s government be stripped of his regional lawmaker role, in a move that may complicate efforts to end a prolonged national political deadlock.

articles.author: Ann Saphir
articles.title: Fed may need new framework to boost inflation to 2%
articles.description: The Federal Reserve could find itself fighting too-low inflation for years to come, San Francisco Federal Reserve President Mary Daly said on Friday, and may need a new policy framework to achieve its goal of 2% inflation.
articles.content:
SAN DIEGO (Reuters) - The Federal Reserve could find itself fighting too-low inflation for years to come, San Francisco Federal Reserve President Mary Daly said on Friday, and may need a new policy framework to achieve its goal of 2% inflation.

articles.title: UPDATE 1-Mexico concludes 2020 oil hedge at $49 per barrel - finance ministry
articles.description: Mexico has completed its annual oil hedging program for 2020, the finance ministry said on Friday, after unprecedented challenges slowed the world's largest financial oil deal this year.

MEXICO CITY, Jan 3 (Reuters) - Mexico has completed its annual oil hedging program for 2020, the finance ministry said on Friday, after unprecedented challenges slowed the world’s largest financial oil deal this year.

articles.title: Commuters may get less sleep and exercise
articles.description: (Reuters Health) – People with full-time jobs who endure long commutes may be more likely to have sleep problems and sedentary lifestyles than counterparts who work closer to home, a Swedish study suggests.
articles.content:
